channel.description: Stay up to date on everything happening in The New Yorker and on newyorker.com.

item.title: Political Scene: Unemployment and the Recovery’s Mixed Signals
item.description: Dorothy Wickenden hosts John Cassidy and James Surowiecki on this week’s Political Scene podcast to discuss the still-uneven economic recovery.
item.dc:creator: Matthew McKnight

item.title: The Cultural Fight for Guns
item.description: The real argument about guns is becoming not primarily an argument about public safety or public health but an argument about cultural symbols…
item.dc:creator: Adam Gopnik

item.title: M.L.K., Jr., Forty-Five Years Later: The Forgotten Moral
item.description: Forty-five years ago today, Martin Luther King, Jr., stepped onto the balcony of the Lorraine Motel and thus into eternity.
item.dc:creator: Jelani Cobb

item.title: God Calls
item.description: Anatole Broyard was God. He lived on Parnassus, and he sent down his golden words for mortals to read. I was baffled by two things: one, that God would be calling me, and two, that he would speak with a Brooklyn accent.
item.dc:creator: Roxana Robinson

item.title: Forty-Five Years Ago: Martin Luther King, Jr.
item.description: On April 3, 1968, Martin Luther King, Jr., delivered one of his most famous speeches, “I’ve Been to the Mountain Top.” It was also his last—he was assassinated the next day, at the Loraine Motel, in Memphis, Tennessee, forty-five years ago today.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Video: Jeremy Denk’s Piano Lessons
item.description: In Jeremy Denk’s Personal History in the magazine this week, the pianist recounts his “life in piano lessons.” In this video, he discusses two of his important teachers, William Leland and György Sebok.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: How to Make a Great Kids’ App
item.description: I hoped that the apps’ homely themes were all part of a plan. So I met with Toca Boca’s C.E.O.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Lange

item.title: Book News: Cabinet in Court, Icy Words
item.description: Award-winning author and screenwriter Ruth Prawer Jhabvala has died at eighty-five. (Read about her contributions to The New Yorker here.) Cabinet magazine goes on trial at the New York Public Library. Sasha Frere-Jones reports....
item.dc:creator: Andrea DenHoed

item.title: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala’s Stories
item.description: This morning, the writer Ruth Prawer Jhabvala passed away, at the age of eighty-five. Beginning in 1957, Jhabvala published thirty-one stories in The New Yorker; her most recent story, “The Judge’s Will,” was published only a few weeks ago, in the March 25th issue.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Rothman

item.title: Chip Taylor’s “The Last Video”
item.description: Chip Taylor's new single is “The Last Video,” a vaguely apocalyptic and stubbornly hopeful tribute to the characters who populate society’s margins.
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: The Number: $141
item.description: The value of bitcoins has risen astronomically in a short period of time...
item.dc:creator: Nick Traverse

item.title: Beautiful Failures: Nabokov and Flaubert’s Early Attempts
item.description: A first novel is like spring lamb, tender and pink. But then there are the real treasures, the rehearsals that never got published, the artifacts that invite you to reconstruct what an author wanted to do, before she did it: among them, the early works of Nabokov and Flaubert.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Lytal

item.title: Book News: Scott and Zelda, Rethinking “Illegal”
item.description: Laurie Halse Anderson’s novel “Speak” sparks a campaign to teach boys how to talk about rape. “You and I have been happy; we haven’t been happy just once, we’ve been happy a thousand times.”...
item.dc:creator: Rega Jha

item.title: Backblogged: National Magazine Award Nominees
item.description: Selections from The New Yorker's Five National Magazine Award Finalists.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: A Black Flag in Raqqa
item.description: In early March, Raqqa city, although relatively late to join the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad, became the first of Syria’s fourteen provincial capitals to fall from his grip.
item.dc:creator: Rania Abouzeid

item.title: What You Won’t Learn from Writers’ Letters
item.description: Reading an author’s letters is often an unsatisfying experience. Yet reading a correspondence can occasion feelings of kinship with a writer stronger than those brought on by a novel or poem.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Hedin

item.title: Petula Clark’s Pop Comeback, at Age Eighty
item.description: Petula Clark is releasing her first English-language record of new material in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: A New Kind of First Lady for China
item.description: Already, Peng Liyuan has distinguished herself from her immediate predecessors, who kept clear of the limelight.
item.dc:creator: Jiayang Fan

item.title: The Thrill of Proust’s Handwriting
item.description: A current exhibition at the Morgan Library honors of the hundredth anniversary of the publication, in November of 1913, of “Du Côté de Chez Swann” (“Swann’s Way”).
item.dc:creator: Mary Hawthorne

item.title: Beethoven Dada
item.description: Sometime around 1920, the German composer Stefan Wolpe played eight recordings of Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony at different speeds...
item.dc:creator: Alex Ross

item.title: My Stamp Collection
item.description: I think we believed that one day our collections would be valuable, that these so-called “plates” of four stamps were sought after by collectors. Or maybe we were just indulging in the joy that comes from collecting things.
item.dc:creator: Stuart McLean

item.title: Book News: Publishing Pranks, The Value of Bookworms
item.description: A new study claims that Shakespeare was a “ruthless businessman” who evaded taxes and stockpiled food to sell at high prices in times of shortage. In the Atlantic, Jordan Weissmann explains why the book-fanatic...
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: Fiction Podcast: Margaret Atwood Reads Mavis Gallant
item.description: On this month’s fiction podcast, Atwood reads “Voices in Snow,” which appeared in The New Yorker in 1976—one of the dozens of stories that Gallant has published here in the course of over fifty years.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Books to Watch Out For: April
item.description: Notes from the book closet on forthcoming titles that caught our eye.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Wild Horses in Grand Central
item.description: The artist Nick Cave’s creations, which he calls Soundsuits took the form of colorful horse-like sculptures, made of shaggy, vibrantly dyed raffia that dancers will wear twice daily, from March 25th to 31st, in Grand Central Station, for a twenty-some-minute performance titled “Heard NY.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Allen

item.title: Video: Hem’s “Seven Angels”
item.description: Next week, Hem releases its fifth album, “Departure and Farewell.” It’s a classic Hem record—somewhat indescribable, always very accessible, and often deeply moving—and we’re proud to première a video of a song on it, “Seven Angels,”
item.dc:creator: John Donohue

item.title: Book News: Baseball Books, Sex-Ed for Writers
item.description: Laura Miller asks if too much literary experimentation and trickery in a novel comes at the expense of reader investment. Hollywood studios, each desperate to be the first to discover the next successful book-turned-movie,...
item.dc:creator: Rega Jha

item.title: Tessa Hadley: “Valentine.”
item.description: Madeleine and I are waiting at the bus stop at the bottom of Beech Grove in our school uniforms: green print dresses, short white socks and sandals, blazers. In the summer, we are allowed to leave off our hated green felt hats. It’s June, and summer is thick . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Tessa Hadley

item.title: Sarah Stillman: Building your own drone.
item.description: One recent Saturday morning, in a suburb of Washington, D.C., an eight-year-old boy named Ethan Manners and his father, José (“as in table manners,” the father said), arrived at a party whose invitation read “Do you want to build your own drone?” The . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Stillman

item.title: Paul Rudnick: “WonderPlanet.”
item.description: I’m Jyll Cimmaron Stelton, and every morning, even before I crawl out from under my down comforter, I grab my iPad and start to mommyblog. I always begin by composing a prayer of gratitude for my beautiful children: Sonnet, Cascade, Nebula, and the baby, Diaspora. I’m . . .
item.dc:creator: Paul Rudnick

item.title: Mark Singer: Reverence for whales at the Museum of Natural History.
item.description: The creationist’s nightmare that is the newest exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, “Whales: Giants of the Deep,” begins, fittingly, at the beginning. A succession of suspended-overhead skeletons makes the compelling case that a four-legged wolf-size carnivorous mammal that, fifty million . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Mark Singer

item.title: Lizzie Widdicombe: The Vice guide to the world.
item.description: Late in February, in the Ryugyong Chung Ju-yung Indoor Stadium, in Pyongyang, North Korea, ten thousand stiff-looking spectators in gray Mao suits gathered to watch a basketball game. Vice Media, the Brooklyn-based company, had arranged to have members of the Harlem Globetrotters—Anthony (Buckets) Blakes, Will . . .
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Widdicombe

item.title: Ken Auletta: At Business Insider, Henry Blodget’s second act.
item.description: The newsroom of Business Insider occupies the thirteenth floor of 257 Park Avenue South, overlooking the sidewalks and snail-mail concerns of Twenty-first Street. Rows of pressed-wood IKEA desks are lined up under a vast ceiling, and several dozen writers and editors tap away at keyboards and gaze . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Ken Auletta

item.title: Joan Acocella: Dance Theatre of Harlem returns.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">In 2004, Dance Theatre of Harlem went broke and had to suspend operations. A lot of us thought that was the end of the company. Fortunately, we were wrong. D.T.H., with a slimmed-down roster of eighteen dancers, is now in the middle of a cross-country . . .
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: Jeremy Denk: A life in piano lessons.
item.description: Two summers ago, I was playing concerts in Santa Fe, some five hours’ drive from where I grew up. Travel is more difficult for my parents than it used to be, but they made the trek to hear me. They brought along a strange gift—a black notebook . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Denk

item.title: James Wood: Rachel Kushner’s “The Flamethrowers.”
item.description: Put aside, for the moment, the long postwar argument between the rival claims of realistic and anti-realistic fiction—the seasoned triumphs of the traditional American novel on one side, and the necessary innovations of postmodern fiction on the other. It was never very edifying anyway, each camp busily . . .
item.dc:creator: James Wood

item.title: James Surowiecki: Why the Fed isn’t waging a war on savers.
item.description: Ben Bernanke may look like a mild-mannered academic, but, according to a chorus of critics, the chairman of the Federal Reserve is one of history’s great thieves. Over the past four years, the Fed has kept interest rates near zero and has pumped money into the economy . . .
item.dc:creator: James Surowiecki

item.title: Hisham Matar: In Libya, searching for a lost father.
item.description: 1. TRAPDOOR Early morning, March, 2012. My mother, my wife, Diana, and I were sitting in a row of seats that were bolted to the tiled floor of a lounge in Cairo International Airport. Flight 835 for Benghazi, a voice announced, was due to depart on time. Every now and . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Hisham Matar

item.title: Goings on About Town: On the Horizon
item.description: ART SITTING DUKE April 16-July 14 In 1638, Velázquez, in order to curry favor with his patron, King Philip IV of Spain, invited the Duke of Modena to sit for him during the Duke’s visit to Madrid from Italy. The result, a masterpiece of Baroque . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Night Life
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->ROCK AND POP<!--/goatcategory--> Musicians and night-club proprietors live complicated lives; it’s advisable to check in advance to confirm engagements.
<!--goatTitle-->BEACON THEATRE<!--/goatTitle--> Broadway at 74th St. (212-465-6500)—April 7: This is the first of four area dates by Rodriguez in the singer . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Movies
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENING<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->ANDRE GREGORY: BEFORE AND AFTER DINNER<!--/goatTitle--> A documentary portrait of the actor and director, by the filmmaker Cindy Kleine (who is also his wife). Opening April 3. (Film Forum.)
<!--goatTitle-->THE COMPANY YOU KEEP<!--/goatTitle--> Robert Redford directed this drama and also stars, as . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Art
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN MUSEUM<!--/goatTitle--> Fifth Ave. at 82nd St. (212-535-7710)—“Impressionism, Fashion, and Modernity.” Through May 27. | “African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde.” Through Sept. 2. | “The Path of Nature: French Paintings from the Wheelock Whitney . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Above and Beyond
item.description: goatTitle-->NORTH BROOKLYN BOAT CLUB<!--/goatTitle--> According to Jens Rasmussen, a founding member of this organization and its communications coördinator, “The club was born from desires to reclaim, protect, and celebrate one of North Brooklyn’s greatest natural resources—the waterways.” The club, which . . .

item.title: Gary J. Whitehead: “Soldier Course.”
item.description:
I watched them do the math, snap a powdered line. The brick saw whined a red dust. I’d wanted a path
to my back patio, same herringbone. I’d wanted a Weber, four chairs, an umbrella. The foreman’s name
was Hector. I gave him a . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Gary J. Whitehead

item.title: Books: Sonali Deraniyagala’s “Wave” review.
item.description: In this quiet memoir of monstrous loss, Deraniyagala describes the death of her parents, her husband, and her two sons, Vikram and Malli, in the tsunami that struck the southern coast of Sri Lanka on Boxing Day, 2004. She returns to the care of relatives in Colombo, for a recovery . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Marguerite Holloway’s “The Measure of Manhattan” review.
item.description: In 1808, the surveyor John Randel, Jr., was given the task of planning New York City’s grid of streets, and he soon faced threats from Manhattanites. Landowners above the settled lower end of the island expected that they would get to put streets where they wanted, and had . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Gene Kerrigan’s “The Rage” review.
item.description: This tightly plotted crime novel is set in modern-day Dublin, a city struggling to right itself after the collapse of the “Celtic Tiger” bubble—a time when “all you needed to qualify for a big loan was a pulse.” When a corrupt banker is . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: A. B. Yehoshua’s “The Retrospective” review.
item.description: Much like the author himself, the novel’s protagonist is a cultural icon among Israel’s literati. He is Yair Moses, a film director whose prolific career is being surveyed in a retrospective held in a sleepy Spanish town. There Moses encounters a painting that overshadows the celebration . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Anthony Lane: “Trance” and “Blancanieves” reviews.
item.description: Take a mortar and pestle, the heftiest you can find. Tip in generous measures of “Memento” and “The Thomas Crown Affair,” plus any unconnected films that spring to mind. Pound with incessant fury. Voilà: you have “Trance,” the new movie from Danny Boyle . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Anthony Lane

item.title: Amelia Lester: The Pines in South Brooklyn review.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">If anyone knows how to get people to eat fancy food in unlikely places, it’s the crew behind the Pines. Seed money came from the owners of Littleneck, a clam shack a couple of storefronts down; on a good Friday night, when the room there . . .
item.dc:creator: Amelia Lester
